lesson.page: When ropes are stretched by a weight, they obey a law called Hooke's Law. This says that the change in the length of a rope is proportional to the force applied to it.

The value of the constant k depends on the type of material used to make the rope. A steel rope would have a very high value of k, and so a large force is needed to extend the rope. A rubber rope would have a much lower value of k, and so would be easier to stretch.
